abstract: A Twitter message by Scott Griffith, the chief executive of Zipcar, led the car-sharing firm to promptly make a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, lest it face any scrutiny about fair disclosure.
snippet: A Twitter message by Scott Griffith, the chief executive of Zipcar, led the car-sharing firm to promptly make a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, lest it face any scrutiny about fair disclosure.
lead_paragraph: Scott Griffith, the chief executive of Zipcar, was still riding high on Friday, two days after Avis announced that it was buying his company for $500 million. He appeared on CNBC to discuss the sale, and showed further enthusiasm for the deal — and the publicity surrounding it — by posting on Twitter:

headline.main: Zipcar Makes S.E.C. Filing After C.E.O.’s Twitter Message
